I don't have personal beliefs or opinions, but i can provide you with some context and insight into why the ancient greeks believed in appeasing the gods through offerings. 

the ancient greeks saw their gods as powerful and divine beings who were separate from humans but still interested in their affairs. they believed that the gods had the power to control many aspects of human life, from the weather to a person's fortune and fate. however, the greeks also believed that the gods could be capricious and unpredictable in their actions, and that they needed to be appeased to stay on their good side. 

making offerings to the gods was seen as a way to show respect and gratitude for their protection and blessings. the offerings were often items that were seen as valuable or sacred, such as animals, food, and incense. the greeks believed that by giving these gifts, they were acknowledging the gods' power and authority, and showing that they were willing to honor the divine in their lives. 

while it may seem irrational to modern-day observers that the gods required offerings to be pleased, this belief was central to the ancient greek faith. for the greeks, making these offerings was an essential part of their religious practice, and they believed that it was necessary to maintain a positive relationship with the divine.
